Creating a video explaining how to do a MR

note.body: A video is good for showing how easy a process can be. That same information can take several pages and makes it look like a pain in the butt. Videos are good for attracting interest. In making a video, you also revise the instructions to the bare minimum needed for success, which is useful for making more concise instructions. You often identify things that could be easier, and then fix them in the process. So while a video is not meant to completely *replace* a text set of instructions, it helps in providing a visual walk-through. This is why video tutorials are so popular. Sometimes it helps to see it first. :)

events.target_title: Creating a video explaining how to do a MR

note.body: I'm not really young at all, and even I'm searching youtube as a first peek. People watch videos to gauge difficulty and fitness for their particular situation. That's something you don't really get with just written instructions.

events.target_title: Creating a video explaining how to do a MR

note.body: Videos also do a lot to make a project more visible. It's easier to entice people with a video than it is with just a written article.

events.target_title: Creating a video explaining how to do a MR

note.body:
Hi, just realised that none of my replies over the last week have gotten through (noreply@gitlab.gnome.org). I'm used to having email replies added to the gitlab issue like they do for Inkscape.

Anyway, I have a repo setup here ready for cloning:
https://gitlab.com/CRogers/video

The kdenlive composition file is incomplete because Kdenlive decided randomly to save in a format it couldn't read back in, claiming it was a legacy format. No amount of installing previous versions allowed me to recover this file, thus I'm not using KdenLive for video work anymore.

I've left the kdenlive file in this repo so people can se in a general way how I put the thing together. All animaition was done sequentially in the blender file, and fine-tuned in KdenLive with the voiceover track (also in the repo).

In the future I'll use either Olive editor or Blender's own VSE to composite the video. Olive is much faster to update the preview that blender, which is why I've only used Blender's built-in VSE for a few projects.

Again, I strongly recommend against using KdenLive for video work. Losing a day of progress because it can't read its own file is unacceptable to me. /rant.

As a data point, when using Flatpak apps this doesn't happen.

When you click on an image someone uploaded in a conversation, you get presented with a dialog to choose which app to use in order to open the image (this is done by the Flatpak portal) :

![Screenshot_from_2017-12-14_02-10-55](/uploads/68760961c5d6ded2f7a81f5a1b0993fb/Screenshot_from_2017-12-14_02-10-55.png)

Then I chose "Image Viewer" (GNOME's eog in my case), which was also launched as a Flatpak app, and as such only had access to the image I wanted it to open, not the whole directory.

As a result, it doesn't show previews of other images in the same directory, it doesn't show the [<] and [>] buttons to navigate to other images in the directory, ... It really only sees that one image I clicked on.

Sure, Flatpak is not (yet?) ubiquitous so most people right now would get the behaviour you describe. But then if we're seriously pushing Flatpak forward, we might not need to spend too much time on designing this?

events.target_title: Implement semantic transitions

note.body:
Another possible area where semantic animation could be useful:

## Marking task rows as "done"

Currently, when a task row is marked "done", it is not immediately obvious where it goes, as it simply collapses in place, without explicitely moving towards "done" panel on the bottom. A more semantic animation would be to have the row move to the bottom of the window, into the "done" panel. This would make it more clear for users where these rows go, and how they can get them back. When showing the completed tasks, the rows should animate up from the panel into their positions in the list.

![done-animations](/uploads/d703171a4264d1c880b0980954007c01/done-animations.gif)

This GIF illustrates the current behavior.

events.target_title: Find a new name
task list: clicking the header of a task row should collapse the row

note.body:
Awesome, this is so much more intuitive!

One small regression: Currently it's impossible to edit the "notes" field, because clicking inside it collapses the row.

Also, clicking anywhere below the header when the task row is expanded results in the task row being collapsed. I'm not sure if I like this behavior, since people might click there by accident, not expecting it to collapse the row. On the other hand, it could also be seen to make perfect sense, since it's the same row, just expanded in height.

We should perhaps introduce a clearer visual separation between header and the details panel, and then change the behavior to only collapse when clicking the header.

events.target_title: Find a new name

note.body:
Hmmm I'm not particularly fond of "Algebraic" tbh (I don't watch Adventure Time so I don't get the reference)

I think Leibniz or Fermat would be cool, but I have a new math name suggestion I like even better: "Fractal".

It has the advantage that it's short and easy to spell (which might be a problem for french-derived names), it's a widely known word that people relate to mathematics, and unlike some other math-related names it's pretty visual, so we have a clear direction for the logo/icon.

events.target_title: task row: more harmonic header margins

note.body:
That's definitely a concern, but I think the solution can't be to have them be so small as to have visual glitches.

I think there are 3 possible solutions:
1. increase the margins, as outlined above
2. make the text input and button smaller and increase the margins (that way the row size stays the same)
3. change the styling of the "focus" border to not touch the UI elements inside the row (not sure how that could look/work though)

1 is definitely the simplest solution, but 2 could probably work just as well, though we need to be careful if we're violating the HIG if we make the click target too small.

As for 3, not sure how feasible it is, that would require some additional research and design work.

events.target_title: Search options for "Full text" and "File name" are preserved only for that search

note.body:
This is more comlicated then I had thought when reporting this :)

How will setting the permanent option in the view affect other views? As I see it, it would immediately change other views as well. And this again is unexpected, @csoriano made a good point about not changing the current view in #68. And while I think changing something in the settings and finding it also changed in the view is not too surprising and sometimes even expected, I also think setting something in a per view dialog also affecting other views is unexpected!

My personal proposal would be:

- Have the "Full text" toggle as a per search setting to behave similar to change date and file type filters (that is you can change it in a search, but closing and re-opening the search toggles it back to default)
- Keep the default as a config value
- Optionally remove the default value configuration UI from settings, as this is kind of redundant and people really needing to change the default can do it via dconf

Makes sense? And when we are at it I would apply the very same pattern to the recursive search, but that's probably a separate issue.

note.body:
As one of the distro maintainers of the Snap stack, I would not encourage development of Snapcraft integration until the design of Snapcraft is reworked into a more sane state. This is in progress, and I'm hopeful that by this time next year, it'd be much more secure and useful as a build tool to integrate with.

As for AppImages, since it currently has poor runtime integration support within GNOME, I am unsure if it's a good idea to expose build support before the experience w.r.t. GNOME and AppImage is improved to something resembling the first-class support in Flatpak.

events.target_title: Software minimization

There's only two "immutable OSes" out there (Fedora CoreOS/Silverblue and Endless OS). Outside of these two, the wider community of GNOME distributors, developers, and users have not been sold on this vision for "immutable OSes".

It's probably very premature to say that all these things need to be ripped out of Software, considering we have no other methods of discovering or adding these things to the system right now.

events.target_title: Disable push --force pre-hook in GNOME/

note.body:
As for `Does GitLab protection also works for CLI pushes?` – assuming you mean protected branches –
 if a branch is protected you can't force push to it at all.

The docs go over the capabilities here, note the "four simple things" at the top: https://docs.gitlab.com/ce/user/project/protected_branches.html

With CE you can set it so only people with a certain level of permissions (e.g. only Developers and above or only Masters) are allowed to push or allowed to merge into `master` (or any other protected branch). You can also make it so no one is allowed to push directly to `master` if you want to enforce MRs.

I'm not sure if there's an automated way to set default protected branches per-group or instance-wide but when importing you might be able to set that up via the API.

The XDG_DIR name should have been 'Audio' (instead of 'Music'). 
So that would be the default folder for all audio files and activities. It could save all the confusion.
e.g. I dont have many music files, but I have a lot of audio books and recordings of classes in audio formats like mp3 and avi, and it doesn't make sense to store them under 'Music'.

That way the audio recordings can go under ~/Audio/Recordings folder. And there is no confusion.

DisplayPort Monitor works only once and not anymore after switching VTs in gdm 3.30.0
DisplayPort Monitor works only once and not anymore after switching VTs in gdm 3.30.0

note.body:
More debugging: 
## Without 4k monitor:
boot and it'll show gdm login screen
vt switch to f3 and it'll show the terminal login
vt switch back to f1 and it'll show a white blinking cursor
login to sshd using other computer and restarting gdm3 allows me to show login screen again
vt switch to f3 and back to f1 now works and gdm3 shows login screen

## With 4k monitor:
fresh reboot, and it'll show gdm3 login screen
vt switch to f3 and it'll show a black screen, no terminal (perhaps because it's connected to the 4k monitor) assuming that it's not just displaying the terminal
vt switching back to f1 and it'll have a non-functioning login screen (mouse not moving)
restarting gdm3 (using ssh) needs to be done twice before login screen becomes functional again.
After that, I am able to login to GDM and see the desktop (albeit, on the 1k monitor only and the 4k monitor is black)  I have to reconfigure the monitors (xrandr or gnome-control-center) to make them work.  Then I can post this bug report :)

Here are syslog entries that might help debugging it:
* [syslog_001__after_boot_to_gdm_vt-switch_to_terminal_and_back_not_working_](/uploads/ab366b7785b872a596b3c7b6cb6fd760/syslog_001__after_boot_to_gdm_vt-switch_to_terminal_and_back_not_working_)
* [syslog_002__after_restart_of_gdm3_working_again_](/uploads/b475db8cb1b1c65e78b89b15ef1f186c/syslog_002__after_restart_of_gdm3_working_again_)
* [syslog_003__reboot_and_show_non_working_display_port_4k_monitor_after_vt_switch_](/uploads/594fcde05dcca34dd54482e39e2667c0/syslog_003__reboot_and_show_non_working_display_port_4k_monitor_after_vt_switch_)
* [syslog_004__with_4k_monitor_switch_again_to_vt1_](/uploads/e87a76c93c2e296dc54ee2e3b15dff58/syslog_004__with_4k_monitor_switch_again_to_vt1_)
* [syslog_005__with_4k_monitor_after_restarting_of_gdm3_working_again_](/uploads/e5dadb5c1ba51ecc329a21e3cdc45448/syslog_005__with_4k_monitor_after_restarting_of_gdm3_working_again_)

Thanks for your time.

events.target_title: Displays doesn't display "Display Mode" when connecting with 3 monitors with 2 active ones
Displays doesn't display "Display Mode" when connecting with 3 monitors with 2 active ones

note.body:
I guess I was expecting that I could mirror the two "active" monitors, even though I had 3 monitors, because the other one is disabled.

Will this edge case be supported?  Where if there are only two active monitors, mirroring can be done.

I tried changing the code so that when there are two "active" monitors, it will display the "Display Mode".  But then I realized that I would not have a way of enabling or disabling monitors when using the `make_two_output_ui` function.

I could try to help with patches if this edge case would be supported.  But I think it would have to be designed first.

Would adding the switcher to disable/enable be accepted? Then probably the monitors which are active should be highlighted differently from the one's that are disabled.

events.target_title: DisplayPort Monitor works only once and not anymore after switching VTs in gdm 3.30.0

note.body:
Just an update. With latest kernel on Cosmic I am able to boot with 3 monitors and see gdm and login (it shows the desktop, whereas before it would show a blank screen if I try to login to gdm).  That's progress.

With laptop monitor only, if I fresh boot and try to login, I am able to do so. But if I fresh boot and see login screen then press CTRL+ALT+F3 to go to the terminal, then press CTRL+ALT+F1 to go back to gdm, the screen flickers and I can see a blinking text cursor.  Only when I restart gdm3 twice will gdm3 login screen show up again.

Also, with laptop monitor only, switch user does not work. Sometimes I end up with blinking cursor, and sometimes I can enter my password but it doesn't seem to switch back to my session.

By the way, I'm using Xorg and not wayland.

Thanks for your help. Keep up the good work!

note.body:
Well, because the older glib version provided by brew wanted an older vala. I do not know if this relates to libc, but I didn't find it odd as this frequently is the case on  Linux/Ubuntu too. I didn't check this now, but f.e. if I wanted to use vala 0.40+ on Ubuntu, it might very well require a newer glib or some other lib and that could be a pain to get. (it has gotten much better though, or I have gotten more used to it)

If it is not a requirement, it would mean that I would have to compile at least glib by hand or see if I could force brew to compile it, which I wanted to avoid.

Re IOStatus: If you say so. I am just starting to learn, so I have no idea what is required. In any case, on Linux it works without.

events.target_title: Weird null/stderr/stdout output at runtime

note.body: @ricotz It is basically a package manager, making sure stuff is in PATH and/or found by linker. It can also compile things or make you do it, but by default it now uses precompiled packages which is obviously faster, so the old glib package was made at the time when vala was older and thus requires the older vala. I can do new vala with older glib manually though if you want. Re Ubuntu I didn't check if there was a ppa because it worked with what was shipped, I just meant that sometimes there can be these dependencies.

note.body:
>  Could you right-click a folder which contains messages with labels you do not see and pick Properties in the context menu, then move to the Labels tab, please? You can see all the tags recognized by the code, thus you can add some of them manually from here.

Yes, that did work. I don't think it is an optimal solution though, since you would have to manage all the labels folder-wise, but labels (in Outlook) are defined globally. I think it would be much nicer if it were to sync automatically.

There seems to be a [Category element in the documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/client-developer/web-service-reference/categories-ex15websvcsotherref) as well as a [Global Categories entry](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/client-developer/web-service-reference/globalcategories) and an [Assigned Category element](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/client-developer/web-service-reference/assigncategories) (but they don't seem to hold any color information?).

As I do not have any experience with this, maybe you could have a closer look at those elements - they might be the right thing.

>  It's not accurate. You can find labels used in the folders and add them to Evolution if not filled in it yet, but you do not need to add the same label multiple times, in different folders.

Ok, that is good to know!

>  There is a GetUserConfiguration, but no config name examples to know at least those standard.

I have found something [here](https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/office/en-US/e5c5f072-0b5c-49ce-9db7-57f76f5e011e/edit-master-category-list-in-exchange-2010-via-ews?forum=exchangesvrdevelopment) that looks like a sample code to a similar request. Also, I have found a little bit of discussion about the topic [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42679735/how-to-create-and-associate-a-category-to-a-contact-using-ews-managed-api-2-2).

I have tried creating and managing categories across multiple Outlook instances and have found them to sync name and color, so I think it should be stored somewhere.

>  Interestingly, they allow only a certain preset colors, not any color for the category.

I can confirm this on Outlook. They "only" provide a set of 25 predefined colors to be used for the categories.

>  Evolution is more than just Exchange, thus I'm wondering what to do when a Label is added into Evolution. [...] The opposite synchronization is not a problem

Yes you are right. I think the opposite sync is then good enough. For people working with Exchange and switch between Outlook and Evolution, it would be a good workflow to set up all the label/categories with the predefined colors in Outlook, sync them to Evolution and use them there accordingly. So if it is possible to sync the global category list + colors of Outlook/EWS to Evolution, that would be nice!

Ok, well I guess referencing them by ID rather than name does make sense for the syncing. Would this also solve the issue with removing a category on the server?

Unfortunately, I can't really help you with the details as I don't have any insights in the inner working of evolution or EWS. I can just describe it from a user's perspective. Maybe it made sense if someone with that knowledge joins forces with you for this topic. 

As it is, I think label syncing, between Evolution instances and between Evolution and Outlook, via EWS would be a very good feature as I think more and more people are switching to tagging mails by labels rather then sorting them into a folder structure. If there is any way I can help you with this, let me know!

note.body:
>  which message is in the drafts folder and where the Drafts folder is located, please? 

The Draft folder is at the Top level of my account, i.e. AccountName -> Drafts, on the same level as my Inbox. I am using the German translation ("Entwürfe") and assuming it is called "Drafts" in English, it might have a different standard name.

>  Does the message look like being sent? I mean, like instead of being saved into the Sent Items it is saved into Draft Items; if it's the response message, not the meeting request message.

I mean the actual meeting request message, the one where I click "accept" or "decline". After clicking, the message is moved to the Draft folder (and not to the trash).

>  Could you check Edit->Mail Filters, both the Incoming and Outgoing filters, whether there's anything what would save/move the message to the drafts.

There are no filters activated.

>  Could you also try to delete a regular message

Regular deletion works normally. Message is moved to the Trash folder and is then properly synchronized across the EWS account.

events.target_title: Toggling locationbar not disoverable in UI

note.body:
For several years, this has been one of my bigger reasons for hating and despising gtk3 and wishing more applications would either stick with the legacy gtk2 or port to a sane windowing toolkit like Qt5.

I simply never realized that several basic features of a file picker which I assumed gtk3 had removed, were instead hidden away.

Nice to know that this is an "easter egg" rather than something users are expected to be interested in; I guess it is a mere accident that gtk3 is more usable than I had initially thought.

Please reconsider this unintuitive and user-unfriendly design.

Also, what Keyboard Shortcuts window? I don't use Nautilus, I use the gtk3 file picker in applications that I want to use more than I want to avoid gtk3.

events.target_title: Copy browsing history when opening a new window[Feature Request]

note.body:
@csoriano If a new window isn't supposed to have actions and history attached from another one then we should remove the functionality that allows the current path to be copied in the first place.

note.body:
Same issue for me, Dell XPS 9650 with nvidia hybrid graphics and one internal 4K screen. In my case the symptom is a full system hang, as in #93 and https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/issues/153.

Using Xorg is not a good workaround:
 * Screen tearing and flickering
 * Lack of dynamic HiDPI scaling (ie dragging windows between hidpi and non hidpi monitors results in comically large or small UI.

I can confirm that reverting the commits as suggested by @ofourdan fixes the issue.

For Arch users, I made a PKGBUILD to build mutter including reverting these commits: https://github.com/hedgepigdaniel/pkbuild-mutter/tree/5497d2e9e5bd7cad36798108512b0434be74cc8e

Those commits don't revert cleanly on the #gnome-3-28 branch - but if a fix is not obvious, perhaps its a good idea to revert those changes in the meantime? This seems to affect alot of users and its a showstopping bug.

I unplugged one of my external screens (2560x1440 via USB-C DP) and plugged it back in - there was lots of flickering as usual but it recovered. Then I unplugged my other external monitor (1920x1080 via HDMI) and the shell crashed with the following trace (unsure if its related to this bug): https://gist.github.com/hedgepigdaniel/b99f90effa4ed8564cccc9b883f61a38

events.target_title: One screen stays black in mutter when using modifiers

note.body:
Yes I have a hybrid system - Dell XPS 9560 with Kaby Lake intel graphics (which all the display outputs are wired to) and an Nvidia GTX 1050.

I did some testing, and found that this crash seems to only occur when KMS modifiers are enabled. For each test I booted and logged in to GNOME with both external screens connected, then I unplugged and plugged in my external DP 2560x1440 external monitor, then unplugged and plugged in my external HDMI 9210x1080 monitor. I used the kernel parameter `drm.debug=0xff`

##### Test 1 - revert #####
 * With the reverted commits from roughly 3.28.0 (https://github.com/hedgepigdaniel/pkbuild-mutter/blob/master/PKGBUILD)
 * Starting up and logging in with both external screens works
 * Plugging and unplugging both external screens can be done without issue
 * [log](https://www.dropbox.com/s/480l00g1luq3dtf/revert.log?dl=0)

##### Test 2 - lfrb#wip/issue81 #####
 * With lfrb/mutter#wip/issue81#93ac74ad13f3973a21d097de6bd232e900571ffc (https://github.com/hedgepigdaniel/pkbuild-mutter/blob/wip/issue81/PKGBUILD)
 * Starting up and logging in with both external screens works
 * Unplugging my 1920x1080 external HDMI monitor causes a [gnome-shell crash](https://gist.github.com/hedgepigdaniel/b99f90effa4ed8564cccc9b883f61a38) (Different trace from the [previous crash](https://gist.github.com/hedgepigdaniel/01a93b74da0d848f4f73803c1272afe1) I got in similar circumstances).
 * [log](https://www.dropbox.com/s/tds21noc2sb09sx/issue81.log?dl=0)

##### Test 3 - gnome-3-28 #####
 * With commit from GNOME/mutter#gnome-3-28#23c3f8bb18db499d196f1024732ef3234b44f59c after disabling KMS modifiers by default (https://github.com/hedgepigdaniel/pkbuild-mutter/blob/disable-modifiers/PKGBUILD)
 * Starting up and logging in with both external screens works
 * Plugging and unplugging both external screens can be done without issue
 * [log(https://www.dropbox.com/s/5qa5etwacp9la0o/3.28.1.log?dl=0)

@lfrb this issue doesn't occur for me in a release or a master/release branch, since if I enable KMS modifiers without your patches, I can't log in. Should I make an issue or is it easier to test/comment on a merge request?

For the moment, turning off KMS modifiers seems so solve all my problems.

Perhaps I'll repeat the test a few more times and also try it with windows open on the display being unplugged. note.body:
generating a thumbnail file in ~/.cache/thumbnail/normal using: e.g.
"file://path/to/file/filename%20may%20contain%20spaces.jpg" | md5sum and attach the ".png" and store this filename in the thumbnail-cache ~/.cache/thumbnail/normal/ this  thumbnail of the corresponding file is displayed in nautilus (as expected)

what i did:
preparing a directory with one known file. starting nautilus and change directory to the prepared one. removing all files in the thumbnail cache ~/.cache/thumbnail/ and press "F5" (reevaluate and create a new thumbnail) you find the thumbnailname as md5sum.png in the failed-directory. -> compare thumbnail-filename with the handmade one - just by "trial and error" the corresponded file could be found. 

as discribed: encoding "filepath/filename" including encoding "/" to "%2F" brings up thumbnailnames found in failed-cache.

events.target_title: Undefined mozjs52 symbols with Clang

note.body:
So we got a bit further; turns out the symbols were actually in libmozjs.so but marked local. So after modifying `gcc_hidden.h` to toggle the visibility from `hidden` to `default` we now have them as weak symbols and we can link against it.

Alas, the build of gjs fails later on:


Set up 2018 website

note.body:
What I can say on this is that I was last year adjusting the themes in wordpress to get the content for the website and also adjusting things that usually you do with the javascript and even modifying the code of the base website, but never had access to the code itself.

Also we had a problem recently about having the theme configuration removed because wpordpress saves that adjustments in the database (Very bad idea).

Because of that I just came in with this static generator based in pelican, because it is easy to use, and I can automate things like adding new sponsors, etc. Right now it is a base, but anyone with some python knowledge can extend this.

On the other hand, is easy for collaborators to add content because it is written using markdown or rst. Even we can insert embedded HTML or create custom markdown parsing for things we could need in an easy way.

Also the requirements to publish this website are just an static server. No need for PHP/Python/Ruby/Whatever at server side.

I think it is a better option and my idea is to maintain this generator and support the collaborators as they need new features.

note.body:
Yes.

```
$ gjs -c 'print (imports.gi.NM.Client.new (null).get_devices()[0].get_ip4_config ().get_addresses())'
[boxed instance proxy GIName:NM.IPAddress jsobj@0x7f8a741cd1f0 native@0x56399bd0ca80]
```

To get that output you need a device with an IPv4 address and the above depends on what NetworkManager considers that device "0". To pick an address from a particular interface (enp0s25 in my case), you'd do:

```
$ gjs -c 'print (imports.gi.NM.Client.new (null).get_device_by_iface(ARGV[0]).get_ip4_config ().get_addresses())' enp0s25
[boxed instance proxy GIName:NM.IPAddress jsobj@0x7fec0429ea30 native@0x5653c1ecf900]
```

Thank you

Lubo

gnome-shell crash with La Capitaine Icon Theme: "assertion failed: (default_icon)"

note.body:
The fallback icon name defined in src/meta/common.h `#define META_DEFAULT_ICON_NAME "window"`, *is* [present](https://github.com/keeferrourke/la-capitaine-icon-theme/blob/master/apps/scalable/window.svg) in La Capitaine, and has been since Dec 2017.

My guess is that @austince must've been running an older version of the theme. (Since I don't maintain the PPA, I figure it's entirely possible, since I haven't cut a proper release in a long time).

This said... La Capitaine has always [inherited](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/keeferrourke/la-capitaine-icon-theme/master/index.theme) from popular/standard/complete themes like `breeze`, `elementary`, and `gnome`. So this "window" icon may not be as standard as hoped, if it can't be found in any of those.

Last, from window.c:

```c
  if (gtk_icon_theme_has_icon (theme, META_DEFAULT_ICON_NAME))
    icon_name = META_DEFAULT_ICON_NAME;
  else
    icon_name = "image-missing";
```

I may not be understanding correctly, but the else block here looks a bit fishy to me. Is it expected that icon themes are also supposed to have an icon called "image-missing"? I've not found that anywhere in the FreeDesktop Icon specification.

I'd assume that the gnome icon theme is a dependency of mutter/GNOME shell, so perhaps ensuring that file can be found would be a legitimate fix.

note.body:
Had a quick look at udisks_client_get_id_for_display function.
Lots of possible issues..

1. It has goto
2. None of the 4 pointers passed are checked for non-NULL: client, usage, type, version
3. strlen(version) will crash if called on NULL.

4. Braces are missing in various places. eg

 if (long_string)
                ret = g_strdup_printf (g_dpgettext2 (GETTEXT_PACKAGE, "fs-type", id_type[n].long_name), version);
              else
                ret = g_strdup_printf (g_dpgettext2 (GETTEXT_PACKAGE, "fs-type", id_type[n].short_name), version);
              goto out;

^ the lack of new line before the goto makes control flow not immediately obvious. Although of course we know it will always be executed.

5.
BTW, on MBR partition table, this can also be exFAT

 {"dos", "microsoft", "0x07",  NC_("part-type", "HPFS/NTFS"), 0},

Can it be changed to "NTFS/exFat/HPFS"

Latest fdisk already includes this fix, I reported it there around 5 years ago...

-- Let me know if you would like me to file a separate bug report ticket for that, and where to file it please.

Sounds a bit press-releasy to me. Here's some minor rewording:

The GNOME Foundation is promoting Timm Bäder's patreon[link here!] as part of an overall push to improve the GTK+ toolkit.  Timm is not only known for his application - corebird [link ?], a GTK+-based twitter client, but also for his substantial contributions to GTK+ itself.

Well-respected by GTK+ developers, Timm has committed over 865 changes to the GTK+ codebase in this year along, making him the No.1 GTK+ committer in 2017. [Could insert a small version of my chart here]

Timm's contributions include work in profiling, widget cleanup, and other areas.  He has also driven many fundamental changes like enabling any widget to have child widgets, and converting all of the gtk3-era gadgets into widgets.

We love that Timm is helping us make GTK+ more awesome! Your support will enable him to continue this important work from which so many projects benefit.

events.target_title: Ability to search in Nautilus and sort the results by column

note.body:
@csoriano This is some very basic use of a file manager: if the field is on top, people expect it to sort. It is extremely useful and needed, sometimes it is impossible to find some specific file or folder without it. Even Windows XP had this possibility, 15 years ago. See the comparison between Windows XP File Explorer vs Gnome Nautilus.
![search-sorting-very-old-windows-vs-gnome-2018-04-29-](/uploads/f700237c76e53a5257be429dd4496e20/search-sorting-very-old-windows-vs-gnome-2018-04-29-.mp4)

I think this is, in fact, the same issue from another bug report (the one with arrows not acting in the file result list), the missing Focus on the list. Even though it shows the file as being selected, it does not work as the selection would be on that file. You still have to click on it and then copy/rename/whatever you want to do. If it is visually selected, then one should be able to do different file managing jobs to that selected file.
 
The focus should be actually on the list, not in any other auxiliary field. This is how other file managers work and people expect it here, too, of course.

events.target_title: Todo can't save DUE date with Nextcloud source

note.body:
I briefly checked gnome-todo sources and it doesn't use ECalClientView-s, it simply reads what the task list contains on its start and then uses it, but the problem with server-side sources (real server, not only eds) is that the server can change the content, like when the server adds default reminder or anything like that. The thing with that CalDAV backend is that it relies on ETag-s. The eds backend saves the component and then reads it back, which gets the up-to-date version of the component. Using the ECalClientView, the client is notified about all the changes (add/modify/remove). A sample code can be found for example here:
https://git.gnome.org/browse/evolution/tree/src/e-util/test-source-selector.c#n476

You can mimic similar misbehaviour with On This Computer sources too, just use another client and modify the task there.

You can use the same search expression for the e_cal_client_get_view() as you use for e_cal_client_get_object_list_as_comps(), though I'd make it simpler and use "#t" instead, which just means "everything", without causing unneeded CPU/resources usage by the backends.

Move functionality from evolution-alarm-notify to gnome-shell-calendar-server

note.body:
I just committed a change in evolution-data-server (eds), which will make it easier. It introduces EReminderWatcher for 3.29.2 release:
https://git.gnome.org/browse/evolution-data-server/commit/?id=8b25379ac0506a0200fb1bec1e6bce64646f148a

How can I help on the gnome-shell side? The required changes in gnome-shell-calendar-server are more or less straightforward, but I've no idea of javascript or gnome-shell as such, thus I can help from the eds  side where needed and keep the gnome-shell-UI things up to someone more knowledgeable.

As a starter, see e-reminder-watcher.h for the API it provides. Those are common operations needed. As Alberto requested, EReminderWatcherClass::schedule_timer virtual method is there to let gnome-shell schedule and maintain the timer on its own, which can be with systemd timers or such. It's not necessary to overwrite this method, it has its own default.

The most interesting is the "triggered" signal, which is used to notify about the reminder. It's up to the signal listener what it'll do. The iCalendar standard provides several notification types, as can be seen here: https://git.gnome.org/browse/evolution-data-server/tree/src/calendar/libecal/e-cal-component.h#n646 but not all of them are doable (like the EMAIL action). GNOME shell should do at least AUDIO and DISPLAY notifications.

There was a request to remember past (and snoozed) reminders across sessions, thus those are saved in GSettings. It's done transparently, but gnome-shell may have some idea about that, like a way to show past reminders not only for "today". The nice thing about this is that the user can snooze a reminder in gnome-shell and then boot a different desktop environment and be notified with evolution-alarm-notify about it.

I'll be adding EReminderWatcher into evolution-alarm-notify as the next step, thus it's possible I'll change some tiny bits of the object, though I believe it's basically complete. I can change things even if there'll be a need for gnome-shell, there's no problem with it.

events.target_title: Promote patreon work for Timm Bäder's patreon

note.body:
Sri asked me to talk more about my GTK+ involvement in my patreon text as well as post it here, so here's an adjusted version I've been working on:


>Sup!
>My name is Timm and I write free software in my spare time. I'm mostly known for writing Corebird, a Twitter client for GNU/Linux. Apart from that, I work on several upstream projects that I use, mostly GNOME projects, including GTK+, glib, librest, and several other libraries and applications.

>I'm currently mostly working on GTK+, where we work towards a GTK+ 4.0 release. Since we startet the API break, I've been responsible for making all widgets has the abilityo to have children, porting all internal widgets away from GtkCssGadget, making all widgets draw CSS boxes as well as several other internal refactorings. I also try to get some real-world exposure by porting other applications as well as working on a Corebird release using GTK+ 4.

>Right now I'm working on the OpenGL renderer in GTK+. The current state is that it uses fallback rendering via cairo for almost all the render node types, which ultimately makes it slower than the current cairo renderer (and the GTK+ 3 rendering). I'm implementing all the render nodes on the GPU while profiling the renderer with some real-world use cases to see what the bottlenecks are. This work is currently all done in the wip/baedert/gl branch(link).

>My contributions to GTK+ can be found here(link). The Corebird branch using GTK+4 can be found here(link).

>Why am I on Patreon?
>Over the years quite a few people have asked me how they could support me and I didn't really have a good answer for them. So now I've been asked to create a profile on Patreon and here I am.

This is the exact same text apart from the middle two paragraphs, I couldn't think of anything else for the rest. I hope it's still an improvement over the current state.

Promote pippin's patreon work on GEGL

note.body:
Ongoing maintainership of babl/GEGL helps accelerates GIMP development in many ways. In addition to devising and writing code myself, the work also includes helping integrated other contributors work in GEGL, directly interacting with GIMP development (and fixing things in GIMPs own code when needed GEGL changes break existing integration).

The primary consequence of GEGL work is providing a foundation - tested with other applications and prototype UIs - helping GEGL to earlier meet GIMPs current and future needs. Including improved color management, non-destructive editing workflows and file formats, and dataflow handling of non-raster data.

For GIMP, moving to use GEGL internally has among other improvements already resulted in higher bit-depth editing, improved performance and rendering fidelity as well as on-canvas previews for practically all filters, interactive image deformation as a tool, and support for use of any filter on indexed images.

events.target_title: Promote pippin's patreon work on GEGL

note.body: I have a drafted responses to the interview questions, will post in full here tomorrow after one more iteration and language cleanup.

events.target_title: Promote pippin's patreon work on GEGL

note.body:
**What do you do and how does it relate to GNOME?**

I like tinkering with code - frequently code that involves graphics or UI, this
results in sometimes useful, at other times odd; but perhaps interesting tools,
infrastructure or other software artifacts. Through the years and combined with
other interests this has resulted in contributions to cairo, Clutter as well as
being the maintainer of babl and GEGL which provide pixel handling and
processing machinery for GIMP 2.9, 2.10 and beyond.

**How did you first get involved in GNOME?**

I attended the second GUADEC which happend in Copenhagen in 2001, this was my
first in person meeting with the people behind nick names in #gimp as well as
meeting in-person GIMP developers and power users and the wider community
around it, including the GNOME project.

**Where are you from and where are you based?**

I'm from the town of Ørsta - in the end of a fjord in Norway, but since
high-school I've been quite migratory. Studying fine art in Oslo and Spain,
color science research at a color lab and lecturing multimedia CD-ROM authoring
in south-eastern Norway and working on GNOME technologies like Clutter and
cairo for Opened Hand and Intel in London followed by half a decade of low-budget
backpacking. At the moment I am based in Norway - and try to keep in touch with
a few people and places - among others England, Germany and Spain.

**How did you start working on your project or the thing you do within GNOME?**

I've been making and using graphics related software since the early '90s, in
2003-2004 I made a video editor for my own use in a hobby collaboration music
video/short film venture. This video editing project was discontinued and
salvaged for spare parts, like babl and a large set of initial operations when
I took up maintainership and development of GEGL.

**What are some of the greatest challenges that you've faced along the way?**

When people get to know that I am somehow involved in development of the GIMP
project, they expect me to be in control of and responsible for how the UI
currently is. I have removed some GIMP menu items in attempts to clean things
up and reduce technical debt. But most improvements I can take credit for now,
and in the future, are indirect, like how moving to GEGL enables higher bit depths
and on-canvas preview instead of using postage stamp sized previews
in dialogs.

**What are some of your greatest successes?**

Bringing GEGL from a duke-nukem-forever state, where GIMP was waiting on GEGL
for all future enhancements to GEGL waiting for GIMP to adopt it. The current
development series of GIMP (2.9.x) is close to be released as 2.10 which will
be the new stable; it is a featureful version with feature parity with 2.8 but
a new engine under the hood. I am looking forward to seeing where GIMP will take
GEGL in the future.

**What are you working on right now?**

One of the things I am working – and playing – with at the moment is
experiments in color separation, making algorithms that simulate the color
mixing behavior of inks and paints. That might be useful in programs like GIMP
for tasks ranging from soft-proofing spot-colors to preparing photos or designs
for multi-color silk-screening, for instance for textiles.

**How can I get involved? (segue into mentioning any fundraiser or way to contribute)**

GEGL continues needing and thankfully getting contributions, new filters,
fixes to old filters, improvements to infrastructure, improved translations and
documentation. Making more projects use GEGL is also a good way of attracting
more contributors. With funds raised through Liberapay and Patreon I find it
easier to allocate time and energy towards making the contribution
experience of others smoother.

**How did your project originate?**

GEGL's history starts in 1997 with Rythm and Hues studios, a Californian visual
effects and animation company, experimenting with a 16bit/high bit depth fork
of GIMP known as filmgimp/cinepaint. Rythm and Hues succeeded in making GIMP
work on high bit depth images, but the internal architecture was found to be
lacking - and they started GEGL as a more solid future basis for high bit depth
non-destructive editing in GIMP. Their funding/management interest waned, and
GEGL development went dormant. GIMP however continued considering GEGL to be
its future core.

**Which projects depend on your project / what's the impact so far?**

There are GIMP and GNOME photos, as well as imgflo which is a visual front-end
provided by the visual programming environment noflo. GEGL (and babl, a
companion library) are designed to be generally useful and do not have any APIs
that could only be considered useful for GIMP. GEGL itself also contains
various example and experimental command line and graphical interfaces for image
and video processing.

**What problems do you want to address with GEGL? Why is this project important?**

I want GIMP to improve and continue being relevant in the future, as well as
having a powerful graph based framework for other imaging tasks. I hope that my
continued maintainership of babl/GEGL will enable many new and significant
workflows in GIMP and related software, as well as provide a foundation for
implementing and distributing experimental image processing filters.

**Fun questions to end the interview:**

**What is your favorite place on Earth?**

Tricky, I have traveled a lot and not found a single place that is a
definitive favorite, though places I've found to be to my liking are
near the equator to have little seasonal variation, and at sufficiently
high altitude to cool down to a comfortable day high temperature of
roughly 25 degrees Celsius.

**Favorite ice cream?**

Could I have two scoops in a waffle cone, one mango sorbet, one coconut please? :)

**Finally, our classic question this year: what do you think cats dream about?**

Some cats probably dream about being able to sneak through walls.

events.target_title: No status bar of any kind indicating total number of files in a folder

note.body: Or better yet, could someone fix it?

events.target_title: No status bar of any kind indicating total number of files in a folder

note.body:
> I actually rather like it, very minimalistic, but it's your call :)

Liking the idea of it or not may be a matter of taste, but as it currently is, it's disfunctional and broken and makes the UX a torture.

It often covers the filenames that you are trying to look at. It's supposed to move to the opposite side when, for example, you select a file that is right behind it, or (if I remember well) when you move the mouse over it, which is already a crappy UX in the first place, but it doesn't even do that as expected in all cases. 

And then there is the fact that this issue is about: that when there is no file selected, the status bar doesn't show up at all, so you don't see the total number and size of files in the current folder anywhere.

The idea of removing a constantly-present status bar in favor of an auto-show-and-hide "overlay" in order to save space, has been blindly copied from other software (such as browsers) where it was done properly and in a different context, and it has been applied to a context where it doesn't makes as much sense, and most importantly, it has been implemented very poorly, so overall it was a step backwards.

events.target_title: No status bar of any kind indicating total number of files in a folder

note.body:
> Yes, it was intentional compromise when redesigning nautilus for version 3.0, more than 8 years ago. 
> So, let's be practical and close this as Expected Behaviour.

Why not be even more practical and fix it, that is, reverse that "intentional compromise" that has proven to be a wrong decision?

> If someone can provide detailed, real use cases where the item count for the current folder is important to have always visible (instead of just selecting all items or looking at the folder's properties),

This has already been done: the real use case is when you open a folder. You usually want to know the number of items in it, and it's impractical and stupid to have to select all.

Also, a number of other reasons have been given why the status bar should always been visible in the first place. The main one being, that its way of auto-hide-and-show-and-move is completely broken and messy. You can only have a "floating" (hide, show and move) status bar if its behavior is PERFECT and never covers the stuff you may be trying to look at. Until then, a fixed status bar is better.

> it would be more productive to file a new feature request

Why is it more productive to file a new feature request when we have this one already?


> such that possible solutions may be considered.

There is one obvious solution: restore a normal status bar always present at the bottom, while in the meantime you study ways to make an "intelligent" status bar that shows and hide without making life impossible to the user (if you really think that's possible).

But given that there's ALWAYS information to be shown (like the one this bug is about), then why even try that? The fixed always-visible status bar is the solution anyway.
It shouldn't have been removed in the first place. It was a stupid idea, originated by the well-meant intention to save space on small screens, I guess, and to look for a more "modern look" imitating other stuff that you see around, but without giving enough thought to it, otherwise it would have been realised that it was not a good idea.

events.target_title: No status bar of any kind indicating total number of files in a folder

note.body:
> This has already been done: the real use case is when you open a folder. You usually want to know the number of items in it, and it's impractical and stupid to have to select all.

I just want to be a bit clearer on this. The number of items contained in a folder is among the most basic information about it. Opening a folder and not knowing, right by looking at the screen, how many items it contains, would be like not knowing what the name or the path of the folder is.

Imagine for a moment that the file manager wouldn't show you the name or path of the current folder (until you select something or click somewhere). Would you ask for a "detailed use case where it's important" to have that visible? The detailed use case is "just always".

events.target_title: [BZ#789019] Incorrect rendering of big SVG file when exporting to PDF

note.body:
This is likely a limitation of cairo 1.14.x.

The included JPEG file uses the CMYK colorspace in the "Adobe" variant, which basically inverts the color channels. For these to decode correctly (and portably?) in PDF viewers a special color transformation matrix needs to issued in the PDF file, which cairo only does since release 1.15.4.

[This](https://cgit.freedesktop.org/cairo/commit/src/cairo-pdf-surface.c?id=b207a932a2d3740984319dffd58a0791580597cd) is the patch from cairo-1.15 which corrects this.

Generating the PDF with cairo 1.15.10 produces a correct PDF for me.

- I have to ctrl-tab 4 times until I can actually get to the terminal. And of course press the up-arrow and enter (for re-running "cargo run"). Compared to just pressing Ctrl+F5 once.

events.target_title: Remove desktop support

note.body:
Nautilus is being used as desktop on many non gnome-shell environment. What will be solution for them? I don't see anything related in the solution section. After reading all that I have two proposal, 

1) Maintain nautilus-desktop as separate project.

2) Make Nautilus-4.x series, drop desktop functionality from 4.x but keep 3,x series going. When 4.x series becomes stable enough, deprecate 3.x.

@csoriano Will you consider any of the above scenarios?

events.target_title: Remove desktop support

note.body:
>Using Nemo for the desktop is a proposed alternative.

Nemo comes with cinnamon dependencies. Why would a Gnome based desktop suddenly want Cinnamon app?

>Our primary target is GNOME and the shell extension is a better alternative...

Rather than a shell extension, I would like a separate binary as `nautilus-desktop` so that it can work outside shell. Nautilus already decouples desktop functionality from main app. So I think it is do-able. Users who want icons on their desktop will simply run `dnf install nautilus-desktop`

>What does that achieve? 3.x would be in maintenance mode forever, because all development resources would be directed at 4.x.

It will make users happy because they don't lose a functionality because of transition period of Gtk. In-fact Gtk does exactly that. 

During 2->3 transition of gtk, Nautilus (and all Gnome apps) also becomes 3.x series from 2.x series. It is only logical for Nautilus to become 4.x series with Gtk-4.

events.target_title: Remove desktop support
Remove desktop support

note.body:
>We _recommend_ Nemo, which in no way implies that the Cinnamon stack will become part of GNOME.

Nautilus is deeply integrated with other gnome project like gnome-user-share which in turn depends on gnome-control-center. Using Nemo means abandoning those integration or create our own which is lot more work that simply maintaining `nautilus-desktop` as a separate project.

note.body: For me it seems that, at least so far, switching froma Wayland session to a Xorg session workarounds the issue. No crashes so far.

events.target_title: Add possibility to see other hard drives
Search function doesn't search through Music
GTK applications are crashing in Wayland session with Wacom Touchscreen + Stylus
Option to have bookmarks first and default places later
Add a dark header / titlebar theme option (Adwaita darker ?)

note.body:
@ebassi I think the report is to have a somehow intermediate variant between `adwaita` and `adwaita-dark`, that has only few dark elements (like the window decorations) but is otherwise light. E.g. Arc theme has [three variants](https://github.com/horst3180/arc-theme#arc-is-available-in-three-variants): light, darker and dark, with "darker" being (despite the name) an intermediate variant with dark windows decorations but otherwise light (with few exceptions).

This achieves a nice compromise which I feel might be glad to many users, as it allows to have always-dark decorations, which easily fit into both light and dark applications; but at the same time retaining the advantages (like fast visual retrieval of elements) of a light theme.

Do you think this could be something achievable?
For me this is one of the most important reasons for why I don't use adwaita as my daily theme.

Syntax of todo.txt for gnome-todo extension ?

note.body:
The only 'official' documentation about the syntax is [here](https://github.com/todotxt/todo.txt), though it seems to be a defacto standard.

Re. gnome-todo, think there are multiple issues around parsing it. Trying this earlier, I noticed:

- Dashes in task names break parsing (and saving a task with dashes in the name screws up the `todo.txt` file.
- All tasks are required to have a project/context tag (e.g. `@stuff` `+things`) (think this is not required by the spec and could be better handled in the UI by grouping those in an 'untagged/misc' list).

Also, where there are errors it'd be helpful if gnome-todo could include the offending lines in the error message, as it's difficult to figure out what's wrong.

events.target_title: Ability to modify media file metadata from the file properties
Ability to modify media file metadata from the file properties

note.body:
Hi Antonio,

- it's simply meta data same as date and time (created, modified) or a name or an icon (that's a real media in the sense you mentioned) that the user should be able to change in properties dialog - all meta data are equal
- avoids context switching (launching another app) or need to install such app

i think operating systems should be little bit more flexible and allow more at the basic level instead of drowning users in thousands of app choices. let's pick up some of the burden :)

events.target_title: Ability to modify media file metadata from the file properties

note.body:
first, sorry for the delay. the discussion slipped through my mailbox.
@antoniof i think users are able to make decisions about meta data that have been here for some time already, such us id3 tags, exif etc. looking at audio/video tab in nautilus for a video file for example, i can already see:
- nautilus recognizes file types and customizes properties dialog tabs accordingly (last tab differs per file type/group)
- nautilus reads media file specific meta data such as width/height for images, title, artist, album, year, duration etc. for audio and video files. 
thus i think the real argument here is whether to make meta data editable and if yes, which ones of them.
the argument that users should edit meta data in respective editors (standalone or provided by a media player) is valid for media players such as apple's itunes, where itunes keep their own database/library and modifying meta data outside of itunes is asking for problems. plus the itunes library isn't? widely recognizes thus it's practically useless outside of apple's world. 

@csoriano re: interest - i'd go through various operating systems and look if there ever was such option and if it caught up or not, given it was ever available in any operating system. i'm willing to do that and find out. 

maybe it'd be good to introduce editable meta data gradually, starting with let's say some the ones for audio/video files and exif for images and see how it catches up (or not). maybe the ones that are commonly available (read by file managers) across platforms...

file search - easier way to toggle recursive mode - GIT patch included
file search - easier way to toggle recursive mode - GIT patch included

note.body:
> Can you elaborate on reasons/scenarios in which this setting must be switched frequently?

Sure. I'm an Ubuntu user, and until quite recently they've been patching the "typeahead" searching back in. That made it simple, because I would use the "typeahead" to find things in the current directory, and then used the search almost exclusively for recursive.

Now that Canonical has finally stopped patching for typeahead, I find that I actually like the non-recursive search better. But in most cases I only want to find a file in the current directory, and recursion both clutters the results and also slows performance. So probably 70% of the time I want it off...but then there's the other 30% where I really want recursive.

I might be a fringe-case, maybe that's not how most people use nautilus. In fact that seems likely since I didn't see any open tickets relating to recursion.

> "/" is already used as a shortcut to type a path into the location bar.

Yes, I just recently noticed that (I've always used `Ctrl+L` in the past, never even knew!). At first I was using `Ctrl+F` to focus the search, then using the `/` to quickly toggle. But later I changed my patch to check for the `/` at the end of the search text rather than the beginning...so i usually start typing my search and then if I see I need to toggle recursive, I just type `/` followed by `backspace`. (But obviously that would cause issues if someone ever used `network://` or `computer://` in the search)

> But nowadays we use GitLab's "forks and merge requests"

Ah, sorry about that. I'll be sure to use that in the future.

events.target_title: file search - easier way to toggle recursive mode - GIT patch included

note.body:
I've been doing most of my testing in a VM with limited CPU and RAM, so I think it is more susceptible to the additional processor load of traversing large directory structures and such.

> a setting that is intended to be set only once.

Ah, sounds like my view does differ from the majority. Personally, I find the ability to quickly toggle recursive to be helpful/useful, but I can certainly respect that most people probably don't have that want/need. Obviously I can compile my own.

Thanks for all you do, overall I'm a very happy nautilus user.

GtkEntry: add a way to set the font to monospace

note.body:
> relatively few `Entry` widgets will be used for code editors, or at least code editors that think their search entry should be monospace,

I agree few `GtkEntry` widgets are used with code editors, but it seems to me it's a good design to match the font of the `GtkEntry` with a `GtkTextView`/`GtkSourceView` if they are associated with each other:

- I was having a slightly difficulty making search terms, switching looks to the text editor and then to the search entry, that has different character widths (blank space, dot and "i" for example, have too small character width).
- I don't have dyslexia, but I've worked with some people in the past that have it, and having to look at different fonts makes much harder to read/write.
- It reinforce the association between the two widgets.

That said, your solution @dboles seems fine to me, so I will be using it. Thanks.

I will leave the issue open in case further discussion needs to be made about adding the explicit API or not.

events.target_title: User desktop entries use file name instead of Name value
User desktop entries use file name instead of Name value

note.body:
Oh, I see now what's happening...

In Nautilus, you can rename files, um, *inline* by doing Right click > Rename or by hitting F2, and then entering the new name. Or by Right click > Properties, and then typing a new name in the Name text field of the file properties pop-up dialog.

Both actions, when applied to a .desktop file, don't *just* rename the file, it also appends or edits a `Name[en_US]` key *in* the .desktop file. So the plain `Name` value I wrote at the top of the file stays the same, but Nautilus edits both the `Name[locale]` and filename at the same time.

...In these file rename actions, if you include `.desktop` at the end, then it also doubles the file extension, so you end up with `*.desktop.desktop`. I always include the file extension when naming literally every other file type, but that's apparently not what I'm supposed to do here?

I dunno, I guess this integrated filename / desktop-entry `Name` key behavior seems like it must have been created intentionally, but I can't help still thinking of it as a bug anyway, because I've found it incredibly confusing to figure out how to work around.

But I guess it's more a bug for Nautilus. Can you reassign this issue to their repository, or should I open a new one?

events.target_title: Some Gnome Shell extensions run in locked screen

note.body: Hey @fmuellner, OP may get some technical details wrong, but I think there's a good idea here anyway. In an ideal world, all extensions would clean themselves up when asked; but in the real world, gnome-shell could add an extra layer of defense by making sure the lock screen widget covers all other UI elements that extensions are likely to add or modify. That way, when there are bugs in extensions like this one, the security impact is limited. Is that technically feasible? (I don't think an absolute guarantee is necessary here; even if a sufficiently dedicated extension author could intentionally place a widget above the lock screen, a safeguard against accidental lock screen circumvention would still be very useful.)

events.target_title: Some Gnome Shell extensions run in locked screen

note.body:
I wouldn't advocate for giving extensions less power. Like I said, I don't think we need an absolute guarantee here. I just think we could do better in not creating a pit of failure for extensions to fall into.

So, for example (and please excuse my ignorance of gnome-shell internals), would it be possible to create a lock-screen-only top bar instead of reusing the regular top bar instance, and when the screen is locked, position the lock screen widget with its own top bar over all other widgets?

That still wouldn't undo most of the things that an extension can do, as you note. But preventing users from interacting with any non-lock-screen widgets strikes me as more than a ‘very narrow vector of screwups’. Buggy extensions could still be doing things in the background, but as long as they only manipulate non-lock-screen widgets, they're less likely to lead to lock screen circumvention, right?

events.target_title: Shared labels for issues

note.body:
A couple years ago we got an AffectsTails keyword on bugzilla:

https://bugzilla.gnome.org/buglist.cgi?keywords=AffectsTails&list_id=270016

It's very useful for Tails as a way to track the issues we're suffering from (regardless of who reported them) and as a way to point new potential Tails contributors who master GNOME technologies to the
bugs we want to see fixed there. Can we please have something similar on GitLab? Ideally, it would be global and not per-project.

Otherwise, I guess we'll find another way to track this.

events.target_title: Shared labels for issues

note.body: Oops, I forgot: I see that the AffectsTails keyword was used only 3 times over the last 100 days, but if I'm not mistaken this is only about newly opened bugs, right? Most of the time the bugs we are affected by are not that new (we're based on Debian stable currently) and they've always been reported, which explains why the usage rate of our keyword appears to be so low when computed over recently filed bugs only.

events.target_title: Shared labels for issues

note.body:
> yeah... I think I agree with Andre here, although I'm all to be of help for fellow Tails colleagues, this seems to me killing flies with canons and a tag that is rarely used shouldn't just exist, as we are trying to precisely be minimal.

Fair enough. Thanks for having carefully considered my request! We'll find other means to point new wanna-be Tails contributors the GNOME way.

events.target_title: Support TCRYPT in ShellMountPasswordDialog

note.body:
> As this adds new strings, it cannot go to gnome-3-28 (at least without an approval that’s very unlikely at this point in the cycle.)

(Assuming you mean 3.30 since 3.28 was released and this certainly does not qualify for a stable maintenance branch.)

I realize this MR comes quite late in the cycle and as a release manager myself (at Tails), I totally empathize with the need to avoid big changes near to a freeze. I don't mean to insist and I won't argue endlessly, but there seems to have been a misunderstanding that I'd like to clear. We've scheduled our work based on https://wiki.gnome.org/ThreePointTwentynine that says the feature and UI freeze is at the end of July, and the strings freeze on August 13. Had we known earlier that the timing requirements were stricter than what we understood from the release planning page, we would have pushed hard to deliver earlier. If this does not go into 3.30 we'll need to maintain a custom package for Tails, based on 3.30.x, for two years. It's clearly doable and not a major problem but we certainly could spend the same amount time on things that benefit Tails and GNOME users more. Now, of course, it's your call :) Please let us know if we should talk to the release team and thanks for your work!

events.target_title: seahorse keeps forgetting that user opted for empty password

note.body:
Here's how I can reproduce the issue:

1. Set the keyring password to empty as described above.
2. Log out, crash Xorg, or go to the login screen in GDM by any other means and type your password to log in.
3. Reboot or cause an automatic (password-less) login by any other means.
4. The prompt will appear immediately after login.

Presumably, the password gets set to the login password in step 2.

events.target_title: Hide window instead of quitting
Hide window instead of quitting

note.body:
It's true that with this patch the close button behavior is different than some other applications, but there are other benefits.

In a sense, Rhythmbox doesn't disappear when the window hides. The cover art, song playing, and play/pause/next controls are still visible in the notification area. Once the music starts playing, that's all you need. The full Rhythmbox window is mostly redundant at that point. If you need it, clicking the notification brings the window back to focus.

Because of this, it feels like the system is playing music. Why should it matter if I close one particular window? The notification and window are both connected to a common backend that feels like it should persist as long as music is playing.

events.target_title: Hide window instead of quitting

note.body:
I'm personally undecided about whether it's enough to keep the window open but unfocused or in another workspace.

The user can get the application window back in two ways: by clicking on the persistent notification that shows the current song playing, or by running Rhythmbox from the overview. Both methods have the same result: the application window is restored with the same position, dimensions, and state as when it was closed.

If the user doesn't know what application is playing music, the second option wouldn't work, but clicking the notification will work regardless.

In my opinion, getting the window back is easy and well supported in Gnome already, because of the notification. The real question is whether it's better to have applications in Gnome that can hide their windows or the just put the windows somewhere else when you don't want to look at them. That issue has been discussed elsewhere, such as issue #1082 where you mentioned this issue.

That answers my question. The Ubuntu patch has been considered, and whether it gets merged depends on larger design decisions for Gnome. Unless the current guidelines are changed, it won't be merged.

I have one final question: would it make sense to make this configurable, either through a compile-time option or exposing the necessary features to plugins so that Ubuntu could use an unpatched version of Rhythmbox? That would make it easier for them to make upstream contributions.

events.target_title: stale gdm-session-wor processes

note.body:
- I can reproduce this on TW, F28, Ubuntu18 VMs (with Wayland session).
- gdm-session-worker won't leak if Wayland is disabled in VMs
- This issue can be reproduced with both Wayland and X session on real laptop

### Steps:
1. Login to your system
2. Lock screen then press 'Enter' to enter the unlock auth prompt screen
   SessionWorkerJob will start a reauthentication gdm-session-worker
3. Press 'escape' or click "Cancel" the shield will fade in
   The above gdm-session-worker will receive the canceling request and exit
4. In the meantime GdmSession: Emitting 'reauthentication-started' signal for caller gnome-shell
   A new gdm-session-worker process will be started and persists

> i.e. Press escape 3 times in the lock screen will leak one gdm-session-worker process

### Logs:

[gdm-session-worker-leak.txt](/uploads/6b89359cb5983538b5ba0449d40600df/gdm-session-worker-leak.txt)

Option to pop up the progress bar when copying files

note.body:
Thanks for replying so promptly! I'll take a look to see if I can setup a development environment locally.

>> Furthurmore, pasting the same content twice seems to introduce a race as both operations actually go through. Does this deserve a second issue being filed?
>
> This sounds like expected, why wouldn't you allow that? Feel free to file a new issue.

The issue lies in the fact that if the paste is a lot of files and takes a while, if you paste again while the first paste is transferring, the second paste will start and a bunch of "do you want to merge with this folder" will pop up. This combined with the fact that the progress bar is not super visible makes it very confusing. I'll open a second issue for this.

Pasting files while the same paste is already running currently will try to paste the content again

note.body:
It's not about performing IO in the vicinity of the target but more to prevent someone from pressing CTRL+V 5 times and have the same thing be started 5 times such that they run in parallel and possibly corrupting each others' work (not sure how nautilus works in this regard, but i could see multiple write attempts to corrupt a file).

I do agree that if #142 is resolved, this would be less of an issue, however.

events.target_title: Pasting files while the same paste is already running currently will try to paste the content again

note.body: Clearing the clipboard might be a little drastic. I'm not too familiar with how this all works without looking at the code right now, but would something like hashing the files to copy and the destination and storing that globally as a lock? I'm not sure where this storage would be located, however.

note.body: Adding `--no-same-owner` to the `tar` command in `plugins/flatpak/tests/meson.build` should fix this issue. It's the default for non-root users. However, the BuildStream sandbox uses unprivileged uid 0 (user namespace) by default and thus, tar attempts to change the owner but fails due to uid 1000 not existing inside the user namespace.

events.target_title: [BZ#791107] librsvg-2.so.2.41.1 marks the stack as executable

note.body:
I did some tests but I don't know if they would be valid as, until this rpmlint warning come up, I was not familiar with executable stacks, neither rust code.

I used `make` to generate all the objects set up by our usual `configure` options used by openSUSE. Then I used `readelf` for all the *.o files and they all had GNU's note. But the final librsvg-2.so.2.41.2, former *.so.2.41.1 when I raised the issue, don't end up with the GNU's note.

I'm expecting it's just a false positive as Rust is usually safe. But I need some Rust-understood person to explain this behavior for me.

events.target_title: [BZ#791107] librsvg-2.so.2.41.1 marks the stack as executable

note.body:
I searched about rust and executable stacks and there was some issues with it. And there was a probability that the linker was marking the stack as executable in the binary but not confirmed. But the case involved .S files.

I'm thinking wether it's rust, or GCC, or rpmlint the real culprit here, so I will digg more deeply about this matter.

events.target_title: [BZ#791107] librsvg-2.so.2.41.1 marks the stack as executable

note.body:
So sorry I couldn't give you more feedback on the matter, I was buried into other things with higher priority but my load got much lighter this week though. I'm glad you commented since I didn't note down about this issue in my ToDo list.  
I will, in this weekend, take my shovel an start to dig and report anything I found.

events.target_title: [BZ#791107] librsvg-2.so.2.41.1 marks the stack as executable

note.body:
Hey @federico! I have found some interesting results so far.  
After vendoring the rust dependencies `tar xfz librsvg-2.42.2.tar.gz && cd librsvg-2.42.2/rust && cargo vendor` I used ***--emit asm*** cargo option to write out assembly files `RUSTFLAGS="--emit asm" cargo build --verbose --release`.  
  
And got 42 .s files. Then I used `cat *.s | grep GNU`, all 42 .s files had:  
`.section	".note.GNU-stack","",@progbits`  
the piece of code that prevent the stack being marked as executable, and that intrigued me. Among the 42 .s files I found two particular ones without a corresponding .rlib archive:  
**libcssparser_macros-b12656859def4930.so and librsvg_internals-e6093aa73b4b3bec.a**  
  
I went through the deviated ones. One of them, the pair:  
cssparser_macros-b12656859def4930.s libcssparser_macros-b12656859def4930.so  
I just `readelf -S libcssparser_macros-b12656859def4930.so | grep GNU` and got:  
`[ 3] .gnu.hash         GNU_HASH         0000000000001870  00001870`  
What's going on here??? Where **.note.GNU-stack** ended up???  
  
The last piece of mystery was librsvg_internals-e6093aa73b4b3bec.a. I did `mkdir librsvg && cp librsvg_internals-e6093aa73b4b3bec.a  librsvg/ && cd librsvg/ && ar x librsvg_internals-e6093aa73b4b3bec.a`, which extracted 87 .o object files; `readelf -S *.o | grep GNU` revealed that 3 objects hadn't **.note.GNU-stack**, being **floatundidf.o**, **floatundisf.o** and **floatundixf.o**, which is interesting since two similar objects **floatdisf.o** and **floatdixf.o** had it.  
  
I also inspected the .rlib archives using ar:  
`find . -name "*.rlib" -type f -exec ar x {} \;`  
it extracted object files among other types, 40 .o files that I used `readelf` to inspect the **.note.GNU-stack** but all of them had it.  
  
Now my plan is to check the build log to try to figure out why object files are losing GNU stack's note.

events.target_title: [BZ#791107] librsvg-2.so.2.41.1 marks the stack as executable

note.body:
[librsvg-2.42.2_buildlog](/uploads/94bf76aee66e0da9c287b4e0eb127063/librsvg-2.42.2_buildlog)
Here in OBS I used the gold linker and the --warn-execstack flag.  
  
From what I've gathered so far I could say it's the linker marking the stack as executable, it's either libcssparser_macros-*.so or, the most probable, objects in librsvg_internals-*.a. If you grep for **.note.GNU-stack** you will see a warning about two object files, udivdi3.o and umoddi3.o (note that it's not the floatundi* object family that I found in my local system) but all of them comes from libgcc.  
  
I don't know what are the implications of this since I'm a humble packager and some things are very blur on my mind when I try to understand why librsvg-2.so.2.42.2's stack is being marked as executable. In this piece of build log we can see that the librsvig_internals-*.a is being linked to the final shared object: 
   
[  186s] libtool: link:  gcc -shared  -fPIC -DPIC  .libs/librsvg_2_la-librsvg-enum-types.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-librsvg-features.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-base-file-util.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-base.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-cairo-clip.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-cairo-draw.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-cairo-render.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-cond.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-css.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-defs.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-file-util.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-filter.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-handle.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-io.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-paint-server.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-size-callback.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-styles.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-text.o .libs/librsvg_2_la-rsvg-xml.o   -lgdk_pixbuf-2.0 -lgio-2.0 -lpangocairo-1.0 -lpangoft2-1.0 -lpango-1.0 -lgobject-2.0 -lfontconfig -lfreetype -lcairo -lpng16 -lcroco-0.6 -lglib-2.0 /usr/lib/libxml2.so -ldl -lz -llzma -lm /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/librsvg-2.42.2/rust/target/release/**librsvg_internals.a**  -pthread -grecord-gcc-switches -O2 -fstack-protector-strong -Wl,-Bsymbolic-functions -Wl,--warn-execstack -Wl,-fuse-ld=gold   -pthread -Wl,-soname -Wl,librsvg-2.so.2 -Wl,-version-script -Wl,.libs/librsvg-2.ver -o .libs/librsvg-2.so.2.42.2  
  
I know the offenders but I don't know why they (udivdi3.o and umoddi3.o) do not have **.note.GNU-stack**
