events.target_title: Mail disappears while writing

note.body:
I have experienced this bug. A workaround is to always pop-out replies or new messages into a new window.

There is also a similar bug which I believe shares the same root cause:

1. Select a message
2. Archive it and quickly select another message before the IMAP sync finishes (eg, by pressing the down arrow)
3. Wait for the IMAP sync to finish (ie, for the spinner in the bottom left to stop spinning)

Expected result: Second message remains on screen  
Actual result: Message pane is cleared, though second message remains selected in the list on the left

The unselection bug seems to only happen when you disable the preference, "Automatically select next message". I'm not sure whether this is also the case for the compose bug, because I cannot reproduce that one reliably.

@fbruetting @dylanett @jeremiah @s.pantaleev In your preferences, do you have "Automatically select next message" enabled?

events.target_title: Mail disappears while writing

note.body:
I just took a brief look at the code base and, as I expected, autoselect is the default behavior, and then there are some extra actions taken if the preference is not selected. The setting is only used in four places: [1], [2], [3], [4].

- [2] and [4] have safety checks for whether the composer is open or a message is selected. Maybe they're failing because of a concurrency issue? Eg, `list.get_selection()` resolving at the wrong time.
- [1] and [3] have no checks. I had a hard time figuring out what they were supposed to do, but maybe `suppress_selection` or `Gtk.SelectionMode` behave differently in GTK3?

@mjog If you could prioritize this bug when you have time it would be very appreciated, since it makes Geary basically unusable when "Automatically select next message" is not enabled.

[1]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/blob/master/src/client/conversation-list/conversation-list-view.vala#L135-136
[2]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/blob/master/src/client/conversation-list/conversation-list-view.vala#L166-170
[3]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/blob/master/src/client/conversation-list/conversation-list-view.vala#L193-201
[4]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/blob/master/src/client/application/geary-controller.vala#L1219-1224

events.target_title: Not working on wayland

note.body:
One afterthought : Kile does not work irrespective of xorg vs wayland session. If we ignore kile in the lists above, then 

1) under wayland exactly those apps with a "x" respect the extension settings - those with "w" not.

2) under xorg all apps respect the settings. 

So considering kile as an anomaly, the x11 vs wayland "theory" is sustainable. 

One more check: 
Also firefox under wayland respects the extension setting, running in wayland under x11, and also works as expected under xorg session. So we can add firefox withotg contradiction (ignoring kile) to the lists above.

Best

events.target_title: Not working on wayland

note.body:
Hi, 

I'd love to try that out. But I do not know how. Your link leads the corresponding gitlab site, and then ahm, yeah, feel stupid. 

The "Check out branch" button offers me the commands 

git fetch origin
git checkout -b wip/fmuellner/fix-auto-move origin/wip/fmuellner/fix-auto-move

which result, typing them into a terminal into 

fatal: Kein Git-Repository (oder irgendein Elternverzeichnis): .git

So, a short guide on how to check out your branch or how to install the zip manually would be appreciated.

Best

events.target_title: Not working on wayland

note.body:
Hi, 

thanks for the zip. Seems it worked. I did the commands, log-out, log-in (and later a reboot just to go sure). After that I was prompted to update the auto move windows application, what I ignored first. At that point I found the following. 

i) Irrespective of wayland vs xorg all applications (that I tested above) except kile obey the workspace settings of the extension now. 

ii) Kile does not, neither on wayland nor on xorg. 

iii) If firefox should start on workspace A according to the settings, but I start it from workspace B the following happens. On wayland we see a short appearance of the firefox window ( a small one though ) on workspace B before the full window opens on workspace A. Irrespective wether A=B or A not = B. I guess this has nothing to do with the extension itself, however it is confusing in case A not = B. 

iv) Then I deactivated the extension from tweak-tools. This had no effect, i.e. the windows still obeye the workspace rules of the auto-move windows extension, although it is deactivated. Letting it deactivated, log-out, log-in, the windows open normally, i.e. on the present workspace. However activating the extension and deactivating it again, reproduces the effect. 

Now I wanted to see what happens, if I update the extension beeing repeatedly asked. After update the same inconsistent original behaviour reappeard, so I guess, your fix was overwritten.

Hope that helps. 

Best

events.target_title: Not working on wayland

note.body:
Hi,

I just did a quick testing of the updated zip file (->thx for that). And here are my updated findings.

i) Irrespective of wayland vs xorg all applications except kile obey the workspace settings of the extension now.

ii) Kile does not, neither on wayland nor on xorg.

iii) There is no flickering anymore.

iv) Activating and deactivating the extension works. 

So up to kile (in my case) the extension works! Yeah, better than before..

------------------------------------------------------

I am not sure, whether this is appropriate to mention now: but selecting e.g. nautilus in the extension is not unique. There are three different entries for nautilus (all with the same icon). What happened? 

1) I choose under wayland session the first entry for nautilus in the application selection of the auto move window extension. That made nautilus obeye the extension setting to open on a specific workspace correctly - under wayland. 

2) I switched to a xorg session now. Nautilus did not open on the workspace as indicated in the settings. So I also set the corresponding rule for the other entries of nautilus in the application selection of the auto move window extension. Now nautilus opened correctly on the right workspace - also under xorg. 

So why are there different e.g. nautilus entries in the app selection of the extension? Why do they have different effects depending on xorg resp. wayland? 
And if this is intentional, why can I as a user not determine the different effects from seeing these entries?

-------------------------------------------------------


Best!

note.body:
As Federico mentions: you can open the attached PDF files in a portfolio, but right now that is not obvious from the initial PDF content shown by the “main” PDF file (in fact, it suggests that you need to go out and buy some commercial software instead).

If Evince doesn't want to allow/implement JavaScript support, it might at least be possible to detect such “PDF Portfolio” documents, and somehow refer to or just display the list of attached documents instead of the misleading front page?

thanks for the pointers, I installed the debug symbols now and the stack trace looks more useful...

I am running gnome-calendar Version 3.26.2 on Ubuntu Artful 17.10.

I have the same problem - but in my case, the additional parameters in the URL are API tokens and I cannot simply add a file extension to the end of the URL - it's alreayd there, before the parameters.

The resource follows the patterns:
```
https://site.tld/export/categ/1954.ics?apikey=ac383a<...>ab0bf3&from=-31d&signature=f7c964f<...>ed34bc
```

The calendar would always ask me for credentials, while opening the very same URL in Firefox simply returns the ICS file directly.

note.body:
Some debugging info, in the hope it is useful :-)

With verbose mode on the service, I'm able to extract the following information when the error occurs - the full log is available here https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/26492226/ (it seems refine-from-id happens multiple times?)

```
23:52:05:0846 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~appstream::refine-from-id{system/flatpak/flathub/desktop/org.gnome.Builder.desktop/stable}

23:52:05:0847 Gs  possible match: system/package/ubuntu-artful-universe/desktop/org.gnome.Builder.desktop/*
23:52:05:0847 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~appstream::refine-app{system/flatpak/flathub/desktop/org.gnome.Builder.desktop/stable}
23:52:05:0847 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~appstream::refine-addons{system/flatpak/flathub/desktop/org.gnome.Builder.desktop/stable}
23:52:05:0847 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~appstream::refine-from-pkgname
23:52:05:0848 Gs  no AppStream match for {pkgname} app/org.gnome.Builder/x86_64/stable
23:52:05:0918 Gs  failed to call gs_plugin_refine_app on ubuntu-reviews: Got unknown content type text/html from reviews.ubuntu.com
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~GsPlugin::packagekit-refine(gs_plugin_refine;gs_plugin_refine)
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~packagekit-refine[name->id]
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~packagekit-refine[id->update-details]
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~packagekit-refine[source->license]
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~packagekit-refine[update-urgency]
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~GsPlugin::generic-updates(gs_plugin_refine;gs_plugin_refine)
23:52:05:0919 GsPluginFlatpak chose GsFlatpak-system-default using ID
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~GsFlatpak-system-default::refine{org.gnome.Builder.desktop}
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~GsFlatpak-system-default::refine-appstream{org.gnome.Builder.desktop}
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~appstream::refine-app{system/flatpak/flathub/desktop/org.gnome.Builder.desktop/stable}
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~appstream::refine-addons{system/flatpak/flathub/desktop/org.gnome.Builder.desktop/stable}
23:52:05:0919 As  run 0x55b9aebfc140~GsPlugin::packagekit-history(gs_plugin_refine;gs_plugin_refine)
23:52:05:0919 Gs  found new org.gnome.Builder.desktop:app/org.gnome.Builder/x86_64/stable:3.26.3
23:52:05:0919 Gs  running refine with refine-flags=require-rating,require-reviews,require-review-ratings with failure-flags=use-events with timeout=60 on apps system/flatpak/flathub/desktop/org.gnome.Builder.desktop/stable took 73ms
```

The error itself in the code is coming from [0].

It appears to be going
```
gs_plugin_refine_app [1]
refine_reviews [2]
download_reviews [3]
send_review_request [4]
```

I wonder if it is getting confused with the package name or something? 

0 - https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/blob/master/plugins/ubuntu-reviews/gs-plugin-ubuntu-reviews.c#L393

1 - https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/blob/master/plugins/ubuntu-reviews/gs-plugin-ubuntu-reviews.c#L737

2 - https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/blob/master/plugins/ubuntu-reviews/gs-plugin-ubuntu-reviews.c#L710

3 - https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/blob/master/plugins/ubuntu-reviews/gs-plugin-ubuntu-reviews.c#L630

4 - https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/blob/master/plugins/ubuntu-reviews/gs-plugin-ubuntu-reviews.c#L343

events.target_title: Viewing a Flatpak app shows "Got unknown content type text/html from reviews.ubuntu.com"

note.body:
Adding some tracelines in I've managed to make some progress on the debugging of this :-)

When trying to open a flatpak the ubuntu-reviews system requests the url
`https://reviews.ubuntu.com/reviews/api/1.0/reviews/filter/en/any/any/any/app/org.gnome.Builder/x86_64/stable/page/1/`
Note that if you navigate to this URL it results in a 404 error.

When trying to open a debian package it requests
`https://reviews.ubuntu.com/reviews/api/1.0/reviews/filter/en/any/any/any/gnome-builder/page/1/`
Note that this responds with JSON data.

Now we know the URL it is requesting, if we try requesting an invalid package in the debian pattern lets see what happens.
`https://reviews.ubuntu.com/reviews/api/1.0/reviews/filter/en/any/any/any/my-fake-package/page/1/`
Note this results in a *empty JSON data* and not a 404.

So it appears that the error is that the flatpak package name `app/org.gnome.Builder/x86_64/stable` is interpreted literally and injected into the url. (It should probably be stripped to `org.gnome.Builder` and then injected into the URL?)

events.target_title: video corruption with amd RX560 and 2k display

note.body:
Some more details about the flickering:
It seems to happen mainly when the mouse pointer *moves* over gnome shell areas:

* Activities, hot top left corner
* When in the gnome shell applications overview (where you see all active applications / open windows): at the moment the mouse moves away or over one of the displayed window the flickering happens.
* Vertical scrolling in Firefox leads to some minimal flickering (even when not using the mouse, but using the mouse wheel to scroll). 

When the mouse is not moved, there is no flickering.

BTW: I'm a bit in doubt where to provide updates for this bug, as it is also reported for:
* Fedora: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1417778
* Ubuntu: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mutter/+bug/1740484
* Suse: https://bugzilla.suse.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1017938

For now I will post comments here, as the issue seems not to be distribution specific.
But, is Gnomes Gitlab the best place, as this seems to be a driver issue? If not please let me know where this issue should be reported.

I created this bug on Freedesktop. It lists several affected AMD Radeon GPUs.
* Freedesktop: https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=105729

Regrettably I had to restart my session. I took the opportunity to run `gsd-color` under `valgrind`. After a couple of hours it had grown to > 500 MiB RSS. Here's the log file: [gsd-color.1872.valgrind](/uploads/3fed885716887adb947a265e860f7ce6/gsd-color.1872.valgrind)

Most of that memory is unaccounted for; the largest leak that valgrind detects comes from:

```
45,889,842 (56,560 direct, 45,833,282 indirect) bytes in 1,414 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 8,391 of 8,391
   at 0x4C2CB8F: malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:299)
   by 0x58CD858: g_malloc (gmem.c:99)
   by 0x58E5675: g_slice_alloc (gslice.c:1025)
   by 0x590407D: g_variant_alloc (gvariant-core.c:476)
   by 0x590407D: g_variant_new_from_children (gvariant-core.c:565)
   by 0x5900D53: g_variant_builder_end (gvariant.c:3703)
   by 0x534E737: parse_value_from_blob (gdbusmessage.c:1823)
   by 0x534E6F6: parse_value_from_blob (gdbusmessage.c:1808)
   by 0x5350AD5: g_dbus_message_new_from_blob (gdbusmessage.c:2148)
   by 0x535AD4D: _g_dbus_worker_do_read_cb (gdbusprivate.c:744)
   by 0x5317042: g_task_return_now (gtask.c:1148)
   by 0x5317078: complete_in_idle_cb (gtask.c:1162)
   by 0x58C80F4: g_main_dispatch (gmain.c:3177)
   by 0x58C80F4: g_main_context_dispatch (gmain.c:3830)
```

I've noticed that opening and closing my laptop lid usually causes `gsd-color`'s RSS to increase by about a MiB.

events.target_title: Slightly too long "A4"'s end up with big black part in page

note.body:
I also suffer from this issue on *all* pages scanned with Brother ADS-1100W.

It seems that Page.parse_line() always extends the page length if the scanner sends more lines than expected. My scanner always sends more data (empty) and my pages always get longer than desired.

I would suggest that Page.parse_line() should only extend the page if page size is set to auto. I set my page size to A4 becuase I *want* A4 and I *scan* A4. What I end up with is *always* longer than A4 and I *always* have to manually crop.

This has annoyed the hell out of me for years.

events.target_title: How to cope with GArrays?

note.body:
> so it feels like there must be similar `g_param_spec_array...` function

It is supposed to be used with the `g_param_spec_boxed*` functions because `G_TYPE_ARRAY` derives from `G_TYPE_BOXED`. In C I can then check the actual type and be done. Interestingly, PyGI is unboxing the array but then does not further investigate the contents.

events.target_title: Downloader is not following *infinite* redirects.

note.body:
I may have a fix for this see https://gitlab.gnome.org/jwykeham/Hammond/blob/master/hammond-downloader/src/downloader.rs#L44

The default redirect policy checks to see if the next redirection is contained in a list of previous urls see https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/blob/be482fa303823607aa7f91e927cde4947f75c88c/src/redirect.rs#L100

Which in the case of Steal this Stars (maybe others I'm not sure how common this redirect strategy is) it does redirect on itself like so

1. https://dts.podtrac.com/redirect.mp3/rss.art19.com/episodes/cea5f3e8-f82c-439d-89c8-6cbd402b9df9.mp3
2. https://rss.art19.com/episodes/cea5f3e8-f82c-439d-89c8-6cbd402b9df9.mp3
3. https://rss.art19.com/episodes/cea5f3e8-f82c-439d-89c8-6cbd402b9df9.mp3?identify=true
4. https://rss.art19.com/episodes/cea5f3e8-f82c-439d-89c8-6cbd402b9df9.mp3
5. https://dfkfj8j276wwv.cloudfront.net/episodes/cea5f3e8-f82c-439d-89c8-6cbd402b9df9/a88f084d870d25ba1f242e7c495f088bce4cc460d7c183c631be02cdf2469b935bd5b8b87353dae81150cdea81db5eab5eab2df1b5f305351b29ab8056e0bda8/12_StealTheStars_v2.mp3

So I've created a custom redirect policy which tries to detect loops based on a comparison of current and last url instead.

It works for me as far as downloading the steal the stars podcast on the first attempt. But I'm not sure how to write a test to confirm that the loop detection is working.

events.target_title: Passing a cairo.Surface in a TreeStore to a GtkCellRendererPixbuf fails

note.body:
The core of the problem is that cairo.Surface is not a gobject and thus can not be added to a list/treestore which is what you see in 1. From then on you are basically out of options to use the convenience functions on the cellrenderer.

The way to workaround this is to use a celldata function, I have a silly example on [1]. Just replace ``icon-name`` with ``surface``. I also have an relevant example in the blueman project [2] which I did to get nicely scaled icons on hidpi monitors. However it may be hard to follow.

I also never got the cairo introspection bindings to work with this use case, this may be a bug but I never got around to properly investigate.

[1] https://gist.github.com/infirit/ceceb54fc872bdf312cae89b2f2a9915

[2] https://github.com/blueman-project/blueman/blob/a148a3627f71e41bb6ce8be5269d33f1e58ae8f1/blueman/gui/manager/ManagerDeviceList.py#L502

I'm not arguing against meson but don't blame problems in setuptools on autotools. Moving to meson will not make any difference.

events.target_title: login - refine navigation, also an alternative model for discussion

note.body:
I really like this simplified model. It's clear on a single-user system whose computer it is (as well as being immediately inviting with their wallpaper), but it also makes login and unlocking the same which I like mentally; why should I as a user really care whether my computer was already running or was freshly booted? I just want to unlock to get to my stuff.

I think with Initial Setup setting an avatar from an online account (and possibly generating a unique avatar in the absence of an online account), this will is even nicer since it immediately shows two strong signals for who is logged in or last used the computer.

@chergert Yeah, sorry, didn't know it was parsed from the same output that is also printed to the user. (I was pinged by other Rust people because I deal with the JSON output in some tools.)

I'm not sure there is a good solution, then. The "short" error format was mentioned earlier and might be an option in the future. You can get it with `rustc --error-format short -Z unstable-options src/lib.rs` and it looks like this:

```
src/lib.rs:14:13 - error[E0425]: cannot find value `secction` in this scope
```

It seems easy to parse with a regex, but it is missing quite important information -- e.g., the "did you mean `section`?" part!

events.target_title: Merge the DDS plug-in to GIMP and ship it by default

note.body:
Peoples motivations for contributing and being part of a project (for example the GIMP) are diverse, and can certainly be influenced by learning new information. This happens to myself almost every day, when I get direct feedback from users in chat channels.

I don't know anyone involved in the GIMP project, or how they operate their internal priorities. Should I just assume that everyone follows a rigid, predefined set of release goals for every hour they spend on the project for years in advance? That's not how I code, at least.

I wasn't trying to make an unhelpful comment, I was trying to give information that might nudge someone that is already involved in the project and knows the internal APIs and conventions towards reshifting their priorities to perhaps take a look at the existing gimp-dds code, at some point.

My initial comment was written to be helpful, even if you don't see it that way. Helpful to myself, and other people who depend on gimp-dds. It might have been 100% counter-productive towards that goal, though.

This comment, however, was written because I feel defensive and annoyed. Which probably makes it spam.

events.target_title: Merge the DDS plug-in to GIMP and ship it by default

note.body:
@Jehan I was done discussing, as signified by my thumbs-up on Alexandres comment :P So there was no danger of the discussion becoming "more heated".

But I'm going to reply again, because I think it's interesting how text is so often misinterpreted completely. So, two points:

1. I know "the GIMP developers" can be anyone. That's why I put it in quotes. And why I said "someone that is already involved in the project and knows the internal APIs and conventions".
1. I don't have a weird perception of the GIMP project. I was making a point, and using the absurd end of the stick to emphasize it.

Of course, this is completely unrelated to any comments made before @Jehans comment. And also entirely off-topic.

I just find it interesting that text can be written such that it is misinterpreted entirely. It also is strange that you think it's necessary to explain "the GIMP developers", Free software, and the concept of the bazaar to someone who said they have two decades of experience with open source.

The more logical conclusion you should have drawn is that either (1) I am terrible at making myself understood in writing, or (2) you misinterpreted me.

Of course, the most logical conclusion I should have drawn is that you probably forgot I wrote that. Or, you didn't read it at all.

This comment was written for fun, and because misunderstandings are interesting.

Unreplaced autoconf variables in croco-0.6-config
Unreplaced autoconf variables in croco-0.6-config

note.body:
Oh, and worse, the -config script never publishes the -flags for libcroco itself, only its dependencies. The template seems to think CROCO_* is for libcroco and GLIB2_* and LIBXML2_* are its deps whereas ./configure puts the deps in CROCO_*. Compare to the .pc files, where the libcroco.pc.in template has:

```
Libs: -L${libdir} -lcroco-@LIBCROCO_MAJOR_VERSION@.@LIBCROCO_MINOR_VERSION@
Cflags: -I${includedir}/libcroco-@LIBCROCO_MAJOR_VERSION@.@LIBCROCO_MINOR_VERSION@
```

with dependencies instead declared as:
```
Requires: glib-2.0 libxml-2.0
```

Debian hasn't noticed because they stopped distributing the -config script altogether 6 years ago (https://salsa.debian.org/gnome-team/libcroco/commit/0759d363b94e33e7a2b7e8e03bc8c391cf731298)

events.target_title: Fractional scaling support

note.body:
No, please, fractional scaling is the way too go, especially for laptops.
I have a laptop with 1080p resolution, no scaling is needed.
But I have a docking station with 4k resolution, where scaling is required.
Plus, sometimes I connect to videoprojectors, with again a different resolution.
The current font or windows integer scalings apply to all monitors. We need a per monitor scaling.
Also, the font and window integer scalings do not affect all applications : qt apps like backintime, virtualbox or skype do not seem to scale on my debian stretch system.

events.target_title: Merge OpenSSL backend into glib-networking

note.body:
FWIW I still object to this, but I'm not going to be the one dealing with it, so you can totally ignore my objection.

And my objection isn't to OpenSSL itself, it's to the idea of having two equally-supported backends on Linux, which I think is just going to lead to pain and suffering for the maintainers.

> Sadly, the (LGPLv3+ or GPLv2+) dependencies of GnuTLS prevent it from being commercially-relevant

Yeah, and if OpenSSL was in a better position, licensing-wise, then I'd say we should just replace GnuTLS with OpenSSL as the only supported backend. But OpenSSL has its own license-compatibility problems.

events.target_title: Merge OpenSSL backend into glib-networking

note.body:
> We could even start out with it disabled at build time (in fact, that would almost be my preference, except we probably need developers to have both enabled) to ensure it only gets used by embedded system vendors (who will build glib-networking themselves) rather than desktop Linux.

That sounds like a good plan to me.

events.target_title: dav: Default max-conns-per-host for SoupSession limits open files to 2

note.body: The default value of 2 comes from the original HTTP RFC, but httpbis removed that recommendation, and browsers were already using much higher values even before that. I thought we'd changed the default in libsoup but I guess not. WebKitGTK definitely uses something higher, but I don't know what. Anyway, changing the value of that property is totally reasonable.

events.target_title: dav: Default max-conns-per-host for SoupSession limits open files to 2

note.body: I don't think you really have to worry about server limits. The value of 6 from browserscope is out of date anyway and browsers use much higher limits now.

events.target_title: Suboptimal window drawing on Windows

note.body:
> If anyone here has Intel GPU, it would be interesting to see whether this works there as well.

I have a machine with an Intel GPU (Intel HD Graphics 520) running Windows 10. I had some difficulties running in a fully updated MSYS2 environment (MINGW64):
* compiling without `-DOLD_MINGW_HEADERS` results in [compile.txt](/uploads/081bdf9c3e2c72e2435f3a9dcbec20bf/compile.txt)
* compiling with `-DOLD_MINGW_HEADERS` works but `dxDepthStencil` as well as `dxColor` are Null.

After commenting the assertions in lines 773-789 the application runs with the following result (for both `--render-texture` and `--render-buffer`):  
![image](/uploads/d88dee4e66bf528769058351624f4ea8/image.png)

Obviously I'm not sure if that's the intended result though, considering the failed calls to `wglDXRegisterObjectNV`.

events.target_title: Suboptimal window drawing on Windows

note.body:
@LRN - Just tested wgldx3.7z on Intel HD 520:
- `--render-buffer` seems to work properly (no crash, renders a semi-transparent triangle)  
  ![image](/uploads/a84d9b386dc32a0fcc07265dfdf3f6c3/image.png)
- `--render-texture` fails for both, `--core-gl` and `--compat-gl`, backtrace: [backtrace_render-texture.txt](/uploads/cbe21114c30675b93dd898adaedae012/backtrace_render-texture.txt)

Note that after https://github.com/Alexpux/MINGW-packages/commit/66be52cd17fe6f8a7ea2a5417800279c41c2e762 there were a few redefinition errors, so I commented those out.

Let me know if any other tests are helpful.

From the user's point of view the whole idea of `GStatBuf` is to guarantee that it will always have the correct type (regardless of the environment and of what the build system might  or might not do).

events.target_title: Gnome Chinese Community is calling for logo design

note.body:
sorry for the delay. 

please find the below italic words as the Chinese text for calling LOGO design. thanks for your help! VPN is blocked pretty nicely and I cannot access Telegram


*GNOME中文社区现征集社区LOGO原创设计，诚挚欢迎您的投稿

2017年，重庆见证了激动人心的GNOME亚洲峰会十周年庆典。在GNOME诞生的第二十个年头，她的这次亚洲峰会又一次燃起了一代年轻人对于开源的热情。在峻美妖娆的山城重庆，来自世界各地的开源技术大牛和一些标杆性领导者共襄盛会，为我们准备了一场开源技术的饕餮盛宴。

峰会留下的不仅是难忘的回忆，更是中文社区人对开源的展望以及投身和贡献开源的一份激情。GNOME基金会的一致意愿就是要在大中国区，以及亚太中文社区继续深入推广GNOME以及自由和开源软件 - FOSS。GNOME社区人诚挚的期望通过建立此GNOME中文社区来持续加强开源的发展，深化中文社区和全球开源社区的沟通和交流。

我们期望GNOME中文社区可以经得起时间的考验，越来越火热，越来越成熟。此次LOGO设计征集，对我们的社区来说是一个里程碑。我们诚挚欢迎您的LOGO设计投稿，我们相信您原创的LOGO将会是燎原的星火，是我们手中传递下去的旗帜。

此LOGO设计将被用于GNOME中文社区的宣传和各种开源活动中，以及我们的网站，社交媒体，以及印刷品和纪念品上。GNOME基金会也为LOGO设计的志愿者提供精美的纪念品。


设计期望：设计元素需要结合“GNOME”，“开源”，以及“中文社区”相关的关键字。
投稿截止： 2018年4月15日。
Email：gnome@chongqinglug.org  （请将您的设计方案以电子邮件发送到此地址，邮件名称为“GNOME  Chinese  Community  LOGO  Design”）
设计须知：请访问以下链接，以参照GNOME基金会给出的相关设计指导。
https://www.gnome.org/logo-and-trademarks/

此致
  敬礼*
